plugins.adufour.ezplug
Class EzPlug

java.lang.Object
  icy.plugin.abstract_.Plugin
      plugins.adufour.ezplug.EzPlug
All Implemented Interfaces:
icy.plugin.interface_.PluginImageAnalysis, icy.plugin.interface_.PluginLibrary, java.lang.Runnable
public abstract class EzPlug
extends icy.plugin.abstract_.Plugin
implements icy.plugin.interface_.PluginLibrary, icy.plugin.interface_.PluginImageAnalysis, java.lang.Runnable

Main component of the EzPlug framework. EzPlug sits as an additional layer of the Plugin class hierarchy, providing additional features to simplify the development of plug-ins for ICY by greatly simplifying two redundant and tedious processes: a) designing intuitive and homogeneous graphical interfaces; b) saving/loading parameters to/from disk in a standardized way (e.g. XML). The EzPlug class implements PluginImageAnalysis in order to launch via the compute() method as any other plug-in using a graphical interface.

The plug-in developer may add user parameters very simply via the addEzComponent method. A great variety of graphical components are already available and tailored to all major types of data to handle. For instance, a boolean flag parameter is bound to a check box, a numerical parameter is bound to a spinner component with adjustable min-max-step values and automatically handles mouse-wheel events to scroll through the values. See the EzVar class hierarchy for a larger overview.
Other graphical components such as labels, buttons and groups of components are also available, allowing to build sleek and homogeneous interfaces very fast with zero knowledge in GUI programming.
Finally, each EzPlug comes with a top logo panel with the plug-in name and an action panel in the bottom, from where the user may start or stop the execution process, but also load or save the user parameters on disk via XML files. Some of these features are optional and simply require to implement additional interfaces to benefit from them.

EzPlugs must implement the three following abstract methods:

  • The initialize() method is used to create the user interface (parameters, buttons, groups etc..)
  • The execute() method holds the main execution code of the plug-in, and will be called when the "Run" button is clicked.
  • The clean() method should be used to clean "sensitive" structures of the plug-in (e.g. sequence painters, I/O streams, etc.), in order to free memory properly and/or avoid polluting the display (especially when the plug-in window is closed by the user).
See below for a sample code and an illustration of what EzPlug can do.

Version:
2011-01-17: added collapse support for EzGroup components
2011-01-14: graphical is now thread-safe and compatible for non-GUI use
2010-12-20: renamed run() to execute() / enabled threading & off-line mode
2010-11-19: Golden master revision before release (major code refactoring)
2010-11-18: Removed showResult() / added clean() method
2010-08-11: Parameter IO support (via XML files)
2010-07-22: major revision. Many more variables, hide/show support, nicer GUI
2010-04-22: code runs in a separate thread to de-freeze the interface
2010-01-20: EzPlug meets ICY
2009-01-01: major revision. New Variable implementation
2008-08-04: simplified and improved variable declaration
2008-07-20: adjusted graphical interface layout
2008-05-12: full input/output parameter support (box programming)
2008-04-20: new Variable implementation
2008-04-06: first implementation
Author:
Alexandre Dufour
See Also:
EzGUI

Here is a sample code on the left, and the resulting interface on the right: 
 // Sample EzPlug that replicates a sequence a number of times
 public class ReplicateSequence extends EzPlug
 {
    EzVarSequence input;
    EzVarInteger nbCopies;
  
    // initialize plug-in and declare variables
    public void initialize()
    {
       // create a variable of type integer, bounded between 1 and 10 (step 2)
       nbCopies = new EzVarInteger("Number of replicates", 1, 10, 2);
       
       // create a variable of type Sequence
       input = new EzVarSequence("Sequence to copy");
       
       // add the variables to the interface
       // NOTE: variables are added to the interface in an ordered manner...
       addEzComponent(input);
       addEzComponent(nbCopies);
       // ...and this order may differ from the order of creation
    }
 
    // main plug-in code
    public void execute()
    {
       Sequence sequence = input.getValue();
       
       for(int i=1; i<=nbCopies.getValue(); i++)
       {
          Sequence copy = sequence.getCopy();
          copy.setName(copy.getName() + "#" + i);
          super.addSequence(copy);
       }
    }
 
    // structure cleaning
    public void clean()
    {
       // nothing special to clean here
    }
 }

public EzGUI getUI()
Gets the graphical interface attached to this EzPlug. This interface gives access to specific methods related to user interaction (e.g. progress bars, highlighting, etc.).

Returns:
the graphical interface of the EzPlug, or null if the EzPlug has been created via code without generating the interface

getStartTime

public long getStartTime()
Gets the starting execution time of this EzPlug (in nanoseconds). This method can be used in conjunction with the System.nanoTime() method to measure elapsed time during the execution process

Returns:
the starting execution time in nanoseconds (obtained from the System.nanoTime() method)

getNbInstances

public static int getNbInstances()
Returns:
the number of active (not-destroyed) instances of this plugin

execute

protected abstract void execute()
Main method containing the core execution code of this EzPlug. This method is launched in a separate thread only if it was called from the user interface (via the run button)

clean

public abstract void clean()
Cleans user-defined structures before the window is closed.
This method should be used if this EzPlug has references to some structures which should be cleaned properly before closing the plug window (e.g. painters on a sequence, I/O streams, etc.)

generateEzPlugCodeFragment

public static java.lang.String generateEzPlugCodeFragment(java.lang.String className)
Generates an EzPlug code fragment that is ready to use and compile

Parameters:
className - the name of the new class

compute

public final void compute()
Entry point of this EzPlug, which creates the user interface and displays it on the main desktop pane. This method can be called either via ICY's main menu or directly via code.

Specified by:
compute in interface icy.plugin.interface_.PluginImageAnalysis

createUI

public void createUI()
Generates the user interface of this EzPlug. Note that the window is not shown on screen (this can be done by calling the showUI() method.

showUI

public void showUI()
Displays the user interface on screen. If it didn't exist, the interface is first created

hideUI

public void hideUI()
Hides the user interface (without destroying it)
